questions.text: A patient was diagnosed for Cholelithiasis and underwent cholecystectomy. What would be the diagnosis according to the given image below? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gallbladder polyp

 

Given image shows a Gall bladder specimen revealing numerous polyps.

 

Gall Bladder Polyp

 

Majority are either adenomyomatosis or cholesterol polyps and have no malignant potential.

True adenomatous polyp occurs in 0.3–0.5% of the population. The risk of malignant transformation increases with increasing size of the polyp.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cholesterosis and Option D. Strawberry Gall bladder: The interior of the gallbladder looks something like a strawberry. The yellow specks (submucous aggregations of cholesterol crystals and cholesterol esters) correspond to the seeds of a strawberry.

 

 

Option C. Gall bladder Carcinoma: Gall bladder Carcinoma specimen resemble chronic cholecystitis on gross examination, often with a thickened wall and possibly a mass. However, the image provided does not show the characteristics typically associated with carcinoma, such as a mass or irregular thickening.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gallbladder polyps, as seen in the image, are common and typically benign, with the risk of malignancy increasing with polyp size. Accurate identification is crucial for appropriate management.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8th edition pg 79, 1709

questions.text: A patient presented with weight loss and malabsorption on eating specific food materials. She has been diagnosed with gluten sensitive enteropathy. Which of the following can be the safest food given to her? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rice

 

Gluten-sensitive enteropathy, also known as celiac disease, is an autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine. Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, rye, and oats (BROW). To manage celiac disease, patients must adhere to a strict gluten-free diet. Rice is naturally gluten-free and safe for consumption in patients with gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maida: Maida is a refined wheat flour, which contains gluten and is not safe for patients with celiac disease.

 

Option B. Semolina: Semolina, also known as sooji, is a wheat product and contains gluten.

 

Option C. Oat cookies: While oats are naturally gluten-free, they are often contaminated with gluten during processing and are not considered safe unless specifically labeled as gluten-free.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patients of gluten sensitive enteropathy should not be given the gluten rich cereals like BROW (Barley, Rye, Oat and Wheat) cereals or their derivatives like maida, sooji/semolina (as these are wheat products). So, the safest food for such patients would be rice.

questions.text: A female singer with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which muscle is involved? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cricothyroid

  

The cricothyroid muscle is responsible for tensing the vocal cords, which allows for the production of higher frequency sounds. When the vocal cords are tightly stretched, they vibrate at a higher frequency, which is necessary for producing high-pitched notes.

 

In this scenario, the female singer is unable to sing higher frequency notes, indicating that her vocal cords are not adequately tense. This suggests paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle, which normally maintains the tension of the vocal cords. If the cricothyroid muscle is paralyzed, typically due to damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, the vocal cords become bowed, loose, and floppy, impairing the ability to produce high-frequency sounds.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior cricoarytenoid: This muscle is the only abductor of the vocal cords, which means it separates the vocal cords during breathing. It does not contribute to tensing the vocal cords for high-frequency sound production.

 

Option B. Thyroarytenoid: This muscle acts as both an adductor and a relaxer of the vocal cords, contributing to lowering the pitch of the voice rather than raising it. It does not tense the vocal cords and, therefore, does not aid in the production of higher frequency notes.

 

Option D. Interarytenoid: This muscle functions as an adductor, helping to bring the vocal cords together. It does not have a role in tensing the vocal cords for higher frequencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cricothyroid muscle is essential for producing high-frequency notes by tensing the vocal cords. Paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle leads to the inability to produce these higher notes due to a lack of tension in the vocal cords.

choices.text: rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis
pLDH, Plasmodium malaria
Biopsy, Histoplasmosis
ELISA, HIV

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

 

This given clinical picture shows A and B. macrophage infested with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies (arrows) characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Leishman stain) suggestive of Leishmaniasis which can be confirmed by the rk 39 antigen test.

 

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases: visceral (the most serious form because it is almost always fatal without treatment), cutaneous (the most common, usually causing skin ulcers), and mucocutaneous (affecting mouth, nose and throat).

 

Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies.

 

Following the discovery of a 39-amino acid residue (k-39) encoded by a kinesin-related gene in the amastigotes of Leishmania chagasi, it has been used in the format of enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). 

 

Immunochromatographic test (ICT) for detection of antibodies with high sensitivity and specificity.1,4–6 Anti-k39 antibodies are secreted into various body fluids such as urine and sputum along with blood, and have been shown to be useful in the diagnosis of Visceral leishmaniasis (VL). rK39 strip test is rapid and a sensitive and specific indicator of visceral leishmaniasis(VL).

 

Parasitological methods of diagnosis remain the gold standard for diagnosing leishmaniasis. Diagnosis in the laboratory can be achieved by direct examination of amastigotes in giemsa-stained lesion smears of scrapping, biopsies, or impression smears.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. pLDH, Plasmodium malaria: Plasmodium malaria would present differently on a blood smear and would not typically show macrophages with intracellular organisms in a bone marrow sample. The pLDH test is specific for diagnosing malaria, not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Biopsy, Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis could cause fever of unknown origin and show organisms in macrophages, but the morphology would be different from Leishmania donovani. Histoplasma typically appears as small yeast forms within macrophages, not the double dot appearance seen here.

 

Option D. ELISA, HIV: While HIV can present with fever of unknown origin, it would not directly explain the bone marrow findings of intracellular Leishmania bodies. An ELISA test for HIV is not relevant to diagnosing the cause of the observed bone marrow pathology.

 

Educational Objective

 

The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Correct about rheumatoid arthritis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autoimmunity

 

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disorder of autoimmune origin.

 

The following steps outline pathogenesis of RA:

 

  1. Genetic Predisposition: Certain human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class II genes, particularly the HLA-DRB1 gene, have been strongly associated with an increased risk of developing RA.
  2. Environmental Triggers: Environmental factors, such as infections, smoking, and hormonal influences, are believed to trigger the development of RA in genetically susceptible individuals.
  3. Autoimmunity: In RA, the immune system mistakenly targets and attacks the body's own tissues, particularly the synovial membrane lining the joints. Autoantibodies, such as rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, are commonly present in individuals with RA. These antibodies contribute to the autoimmune response by targeting self-antigens and promoting inflammation.
  4. Synovial Inflammation: The initial inflammatory response in RA occurs within the synovium, leading to synovitis. Activated immune cells, such as T cells and macrophages, infiltrate the synovial membrane, releasing pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), interleukin-1 (IL-1), and interleukin-6 (IL-6). These cytokines promote further inflammation and contribute to the destruction of joint tissues.
  5. Pannus Formation: Prolonged synovial inflammation leads to the formation of a pannus, an invasive synovial tissue mass. The pannus consists of activated synovial fibroblasts, immune cells, and newly formed blood vessels. The pannus invades and destroys cartilage, bone, and other joint structures, leading to joint deformities and functional impairment.
  6. Bone Erosion and Cartilage Destruction: The pannus, along with the release of enzymes, such as matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), promotes the erosion and destruction of bone and cartilage. MMPs degrade the extracellular matrix components, contributing to joint damage and irreversible structural changes.
  7. Systemic Manifestations: Rheumatoid arthritis is not limited to the joints and can involve multiple organs and systems. Systemic inflammation can lead to complications such as rheumatoid nodules, rheumatoid lung disease, vasculitis, pericarditis, and involvement of other tissues.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IgE Mediated: IgE-mediated responses are characteristic of Type I hypersensitivity reactions, not RA.

 

Option B. Defective Cellular and Humoral Immunity: While immune dysfunction is a component of RA, it is specifically an autoimmune disorder, not just a general defect in immunity.

 

Option D. Chronic Microbial Infections: RA is not caused by chronic microbial infections, although infections can trigger its onset in genetically predisposed individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Imp. Characteristic features of RA:

  • Synovial cell hyperplasia and proliferation
  • Dense inflammatory infiltrates
  • Osteoclastic activity in the underlying bone
  • Subcutaneous nodule

questions.text: A mother comes to the hospital with her newborn baby. On examination, surfactants are not adequately found and collapse of alveoli was seen. What will be the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory distress syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) is a condition commonly seen in premature infants where the lungs are not fully developed, leading to a deficiency in surfactant. Surfactant is crucial for reducing surface tension within the alveoli, allowing them to remain open and facilitating proper gas exchange. Without adequate surfactant, the alveoli collapse, leading to impaired gas exchange and difficulty breathing, which is the hallmark of RDS. In this case, the mother's newborn shows signs of inadequate surfactant and alveolar collapse, making RDS the most probable diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchial asthma: This condition involves chronic inflammation of the airways, typically seen in older children and adults, not newborns. It presents with symptoms such as wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath but is not associated with surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Option C. Pneumonia: This is an infection of the lungs that can cause fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. While it can affect newborns, it does not involve surfactant deficiency or the collapse of alveoli.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: This condition involves the accumulation of fluid in the pleural space around the lungs. It can cause breathing difficulties but is not related to surfactant deficiency or alveolar collapse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory distress syndrome in newborns is primarily due to a lack of surfactant, leading to alveolar collapse and breathing difficulties.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presented in OPD with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Investigations revealed the following as shown below. The peripheral smear is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

Hb – 5 g%

 

MCH – 24

 

MCV – Low

 

TLC – 11000 /µL

 

Platelets – 5,00,000 /cubic mm

 

Normal values:

 

  • Mean cell volume (MCV): 90 +/- 8 fL
  • Mean cell Hb (MCH): 30 +/- 3 pg
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Iron-deficiency anemia

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of microcytic hypochromic anemia for which the most common cause is Iron Deficiency Anemia.

 

Iron deficiency anemia is characterized by:

 

  • Low serum ferritin: Reflects low iron stores.
  • Low serum iron: Indicates a lack of available iron.
  • High TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity): Reflects the body’s increased capacity to bind iron, which happens when iron levels are low.
  • Low transferrin saturation: Reflects low iron availability relative to the binding capacity.

 

These findings together with the low MCV, low MCH, low Hb and compensatory increase in the platelets strongly suggest iron deficiency anemia rather than other conditions.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Megaloblastic anemia: Typically presents with macrocytic anemia (high MCV), which is not the case here. Also, MCH would generally be elevated in megaloblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Thalassemia major: This condition would also present with microcytic anemia, but it typically does not show such severe hypochromia or the thrombocytosis seen in this case. Additionally, the Mentzer index (MCV/RBC count) is typically less than 13 in thalassemia trait, not in severe iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Essential thrombocytosis: While this condition does present with an elevated platelet count, it does not typically present with the microcytic, hypochromic anemia seen in iron deficiency anemia. The primary abnormality in essential thrombocytosis is the elevated platelet count, without the severe anemia observed here.

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You are a public health researcher evaluating a new screening test for early detection of a specific disease in a community. Your team successfully conducted a pilot study in a small group. Before planning a large-scale implementation, you wish to ensure that the findings from your pilot study can be applied to larger, diverse groups of individuals outside your initial sample. This ability to extrapolate the findings in the broader population, i.e. the external validity of a screening test is related to which of the following options? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Generalizability

 

  • Generalizability refers to the extent to which the findings from a study or pilot test can be applied to a broader population.
  • It is a measure of the external validity of a study.
  • Ensuring that the results of a pilot study can be extrapolated to larger, diverse groups outside the initial sample is crucial for the success of large-scale implementations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stability: Refers to the consistency of test results over time, ensuring that repeated measurements yield the same results under unchanged conditions. While important, it does not address how findings apply to different populations.

 

Option B. Objectivity: Ensures that test results are unbiased and not influenced by the person administering the test. While critical for reliable results, it does not relate to applying findings to a broader population.

 

Option D. Repeatability: Refers to the consistency of the test results when repeated under identical conditions. This is crucial for reliability but does not address the applicability of the results to different populations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

External validity of a screening test is related to generalizability.

 

Validity refers to what extent the test measures which it purports to measure (adequacy of measurement).

 

Types of Validity

choices.text: 70 percent of the drug undergoes first pass metabolism in liver.
The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition.
The drug is 30 percent potent in producing therapeutic effect.
30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

questions.text: What does it mean when a drug has a bioavailability of 30 percent? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans D. 30 percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form

 

This statement accurately defines bioavailability. Bioavailability is the percentage of an administered drug dose that reaches the systemic circulation without being metabolized or changed. In this case, a bioavailability of 30 percent means that only 30 percent of the drug dose reaches the systemic circulation, while the rest may be eliminated or metabolized before reaching the bloodstream.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 70 percent of the drug undergoes first-pass metabolism in the liver: This statement is not a direct explanation of bioavailability but is related to the fate of the drug after absorption. If 30 percent is bioavailability, then 70 percent of drug is either not absorbed or undergo first pass metabolism. First-pass metabolism in the liver can reduce the amount of drug available for systemic circulation, but it doesn't define bioavailability.

 

Option B. The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical composition: This statement is incorrect. Bioavailability is not related to the purity of a drug but rather to its absorption and availability in the bloodstream.

 

Option C. The drug is 30 percent potent in producing a therapeutic effect: This statement is not an accurate description of bioavailability. Potency refers to the strength or concentration of a drug required to produce a specific effect, while bioavailability is about how much of the administered dose reaches the systemic circulation.

questions.text: A patient presents with a slowly progressive swelling that has been noticeable for the past 18 months. The swelling exhibits variable consistency, with some areas feeling hard and others feeling soft, image of patient is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis for this clinical presentation? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleomorphic adenoma

 

Explanation:

 

The case scenario and image showing a swelling lifting the ear lobe are suggestive of a pleomorphic adenoma. Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common benign tumors of the salivary glands, with the parotid gland being the most frequent site. These tumors are encapsulated and exhibit a mixed cellular composition, leading to a variable consistency, which is reflected in their name "pleomorphic." Clinically, they present as painless, slow-growing masses. The characteristic lift of the earlobe due to the swelling is a classic sign of a parotid gland tumor. Untreated pleomorphic adenomas may undergo malignant transformation, hence surgical excision is typically recommended.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Jaw Tumor: Jaw tumors, particularly those of the mandible or maxilla, are often bony growths or related to the teeth (odontogenic tumors). While they can cause facial asymmetry, they are usually centered around the bones and are not typically located in the parotid gland region. These tumors tend to be hard and lack the variable consistency described in the clinical presentation.

 

Option B. Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cysts are benign cystic tumors containing skin appendages (such as hair follicles), and sometimes hair, teeth, or sebum. They are typically congenital and found on the face, neck, or ovary. While they can appear on the face or neck, the described clinical presentation is less suggestive of a dermoid cyst compared to a pleomorphic adenoma. Dermoid cysts often show indentation due to putty material.

 

Option D. Sebaceous cyst: Also known as an epidermal cyst, a sebaceous cyst is a benign growth arising from blocked sebaceous glands, often containing a thick, cheese-like material. Sebaceous cysts can appear almost anywhere on the body where sebaceous glands are found, including the face, and often show a black punctum. However, the described clinical presentation and duration better match a pleomorphic adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common benign tumor of the salivary glands, typically presenting as a painless, slow-growing mass with variable consistency and often lifting the earlobe due to its location in the parotid gland.

questions.text: Which gene is not involved in double strand DNA break repair mechanism? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) MSH2

 

MSH2 stands for "MutS homolog 2." The gene is located on chromosome 2 and is not directly involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks. Instead, MSH2 is a key component of the DNA mismatch repair (MMR) pathway. MMR is responsible for correcting errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches and small insertions or deletions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. BRCA1: BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1) is involved in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through the homologous recombination pathway. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers.

 

Option C. KU70: KU70, along with KU80, forms the Ku heterodimer (Ku70/Ku80), which is a crucial component of the non-homologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway. NHEJ is a major mechanism for repairing double-strand DNA breaks, especially in the G1 phase of the cell cycle.

 

Option D. ATM: The ATM (ataxia-telangiectasia mutated) gene codes for a protein kinase that plays a central role in the cellular response to double-strand DNA breaks. It activates a signaling cascade that leads to DNA repair and cell cycle control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 understand the roles of different genes and proteins in the repair of double-strand DNA breaks (DSBs), which is essential for maintaining genome stability and preventing mutations.

questions.text: A newborn baby refuses breast milk since the 2nd day of birth but accepts glucose water. He develops vomiting and severe jaundice by the 5th day. Benedict's test was positive for urine and blood glucose was low. The most likely cause is due to the deficiency of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

  • Deficiency of GALT is the primary cause of classic galactosemia, which results in the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the body and leads to the symptoms described.

 

Classical Galactosemia:

 

  • It is an autosomal recessive in born error of metabolism due to deficiency of enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase.

 

 

  • Due to the block in this enzyme, galactose-1- phosphate will accumulate in liver. This will inhibit galactokinase as well as glycogen phosphorylase. Hypoglycemia is the result.
  • Bilirubin uptake is less and bilirubin conjugation is reduced; so unconjugated bilirubin level is increased in blood.
  • There is enlargement of liver, jaundice and severe mental retardation.
  • Free galactose accumulates, leading to galactosemia. It is partly excreted in urine (galactosuria).
  • Galactose is reduced to dulcitol. The accumulation of dulcitol in the lens results in cataract due to its osmotic effect. This is called congenital cataract and is a very characteristic feature of galactosemia.
  • Galactose-1-phosphate may get deposited in renal tubules, producing tubular damage leading to generalized amino aciduria.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Clinical manifestation including congenital cataract and presence of galactose in urine (positive benedicts test) as well as elevated blood galactose levels will help in the diagnosis.
    • Collection of fetal cells by amniocentesis may be useful in prenatal diagnosis. Heterozygous parents could be detected by elevated galactose level in blood after a galactose load.
  • Treatment: 
    • If lactose is withdrawn from the diet, most of the symptoms recede. But mental retardation, when established, will not improve. Hence early detection is most important. For affected infant lactose-free diet is given. Such special diets may be withdrawn after 4 years, when galactose-1-phosphate pyro phosphorylase becomes active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aldose reductase: Aldose reductase is not directly related to galactose metabolism and is not the cause of galactosemia.

 

Option B. Galactokinase: Galactokinase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type II Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose and galactitol in the blood and tissues. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Option D. UDP galactose-4-epimerase: UDP galactose-4-epimerase deficiency leads to another form of galactosemia known as Type III Galactosemia, which is characterized by elevated levels of galactose-1-phosphate and UDP-galactose. It does not typically present with the same symptoms as described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency, or classic galactosemia, is a severe metabolic disorder marked by an inability to metabolize galactose properly, leading to serious systemic symptoms including jaundice, hypoglycemia, and liver dysfunction. Early diagnosis and management through dietary adjustments are crucial for preventing long-term complications.

questions.text: Examine the histological section provided. Which type of cartilage is shown in the image?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. White fibrocartilage

 

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

 

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

 

  • Chondrocytes- Round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- Type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

 

Note - White fibrocartilage is dense with collagen fibers (primarily type I collagen), which gives a great tensile strength. It is found in intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, menisci of the knee, and places where tendons insert into bones.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: It's a type of hyaline cartilage not involved in joint articulations. The matrix contains a moderate amount of collagen fibers, predominantly type II collagen, making it tough but somewhat flexible. It is found in the respiratory tract (including the trachea, bronchi, and nasal cartilages), growth plates of bones, and the anterior aspect of ribs (costal cartilages).

 

Option B. Articular hyaline cartilage: It is similar in composition to non-articular hyaline cartilage, but specifically lines the surfaces of bones in synovial joints. It covers the ends of bones in synovial joints such as the knee, shoulder, and hip.

 

Option C. Yellow cartilage (Elastic cartilage): It contains elastic fibers and collagen fibers, mainly type II collagen. The elastic fibers give it more flexibility than hyaline cartilage. It is found in the ear pinna (auricle), epiglottis, and auditory (Eustachian) tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida presented in OBG emergency with 38 weeks of amenorrhea. She is in first stage of labour and on examination, cervical dilatation is 6 cm. According to you, what will be a satisfactory dilatation rate? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1.2 cm/hr

 

Explanation:

 

In a nullipara, 1.2 cm/hr is the best dilatation rate among given options.

 

First stage of labour has 2 phases:

 

 

  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h
  • Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a multi is 1.5 cm/h

 

 

The WHO Labour Care guide (2021) differs from the earlier partograph in the following ways:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ideal rate of cervical dilatation in a primi is 1 cm/h

 

Ref: WHO labour care guide Users Manual 2021

questions.text: If a woman is undergoing MTP after 24 weeks  of gestation due to congenital anomaly in the fetus , whose presence is not required for authorization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lawyer

 

Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) regulations require authorization by a medical board when a pregnancy extends beyond 24 weeks, particularly in cases involving serious congenital anomalies. The board typically comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist—professionals whose expertise is crucial in assessing the risks and conditions related to both the pregnancy and the identified anomaly.

 

A lawyer is not part of this medical board and does not play a role in authorizing MTP, as the decision is purely based on medical assessment rather than legal consultation. The presence of a lawyer is not necessary because the authorization process focuses on the medical justification and safety considerations rather than legal arguments.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obstetrician: The obstetrician is involved in the care of the pregnant woman and is often part of the medical decision-making team, especially when dealing with complex or high-risk pregnancies.

 

Option C. Pediatrician: Pediatricians are essential members of the medical board because they provide expertise on the potential outcomes for the fetus, especially in cases involving congenital anomalies that could impact the fetus's viability or quality of life.

 

Option D. Sonologist: The sonologist's role is crucial as they specialize in ultrasound and imaging, providing detailed assessments of the fetus's condition. Their input is vital in confirming congenital anomalies and guiding the medical board’s decision-making process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MTP after 24 weeks for congenital anomalies, the medical board's authorization is required and comprises a gynecologist, pediatrician, and sonologist. A lawyer’s presence is not required for this authorization process.

questions.text: Xerophthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence of bitot's spot is more than: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.8%

 

Explanation:

 

One of the criteria for considering xerophthalmia as a public health problem is if the prevalence of bitot's spots (a sign of vitamin A deficiency) is more than 0.5% in the population. The specifically asks about the prevalence of bitot's spots, and the option closest to 0.5% is 0.8%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prevalence criteria for determining the Xerophthalmia problem in a community: (Preschool children 6 months- 6 years).

questions.text: A pediatrician reviews medical records of children aged 6-10 years to determine if there's a higher history of MMR vaccination in children with autism compared to those without. What type of observational study design is this? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Case control study

 

The above given example is that of a case control study, wherein two groups of children are selected- one group with autism and another one without autism. From these two groups, we want to find out the association between the history of MMR vaccination (cause) and autism (effect) by moving in a retrospective/backward direction. In case control study designs, the strength of association is found out by calculating the odds ratio.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Follows a group over time to see how exposures affect outcomes.

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: Observes a population at a single point in time to find prevalence of an outcome or characteristic.

 

Option D. Ecological study: Examines population-level data rather than individual-level data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A case control study compares groups with and without a condition to identify past exposures or risk factors.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, following binge drinking and heavy meals, was brought to the emergency with sudden onset of severe left-sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder. Pneumomediastinum was present. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal perforation

 

Esophageal perforation, also known as Boerhaave syndrome, typically occurs after episodes of forceful vomiting or retching. The condition is characterized by a spontaneous rupture of the esophagus. The patient's history of binge drinking and heavy meals, followed by severe left-sided chest pain and pneumomediastinum, strongly indicates Boerhaave syndrome. The syndrome often presents with chest pain radiating to the shoulder, which aligns with the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mediastinal air leak: While mediastinal air leak might present with pneumomediastinum, it typically does not cause severe chest pain radiating to the shoulder. The history of binge drinking and heavy meals leading to this condition is less common.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition involves the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity, usually due to a perforated abdominal organ. It generally presents with abdominal pain rather than chest pain and is less likely to be associated with the given clinical scenario.

 

Option D. Peptic ulcer: Peptic ulcers usually cause abdominal pain and might lead to complications like bleeding or perforation, but they are not typically associated with pneumomediastinum or chest pain radiating to the shoulder in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Esophageal perforation (Boerhaave syndrome) can occur after episodes of forceful vomiting or retching, especially following binge drinking and heavy meals. It presents with severe chest pain and pneumomediastinum and requires prompt surgical intervention.

choices.text: Central line insertion
Arterial line insertion

questions.text: The given set of instruments are used in? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Airway management

 

Explanation:

 

The instruments shown in the image are part of an airway cart. The equipment typically found in an airway cart is designed for managing the airway during anesthesia or in emergency situations. The contents of the airway cart usually include:

 

  • Laryngoscope: A device used to obtain a view of the vocal folds and the glottis, which is essential for endotracheal intubation.
  • Tracheal tubes of various sizes: These tubes are used to secure the airway by passing through the trachea.
  • Masks: Various types of masks to deliver oxygen or anesthetic gases.
  • Laryngeal mask airways (LMA): A device placed over the laryngeal inlet to provide ventilation.
  • Flexible fiberoptic intubation equipment: Used for intubation in difficult airway situations.
  • Retrograde intubation equipment: Tools used for intubation when conventional methods fail.
  • Front of neck access equipment: Devices for surgical airway access.
  • Equipment required for emergency invasive airway access: Tools needed for emergency tracheostomy or cricothyrotomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Central line insertion: This procedure requires different instruments such as central venous catheters, guidewires, dilators, and sterile drapes.

 

Option B. Arterial line insertion: This involves the use of arterial catheters, guidewires, and transducers, not typically found in an airway cart.

 

Option D. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR): CPR primarily requires defibrillators, chest compression devices, and basic airway management tools like bag-valve masks (BVM), but not the comprehensive set shown for airway management.

 

Educational Objective :

 

The instruments in an airway cart are specifically designed for various procedures involved in airway management, including intubation and emergency airway access.

questions.text:
You are employed at a primary health center (PHC) located in an area with a high risk of earthquakes. What actions would you take to ensure readiness for potential emergencies? [NEET PG 2022]

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Follow instructions given over the phone or radio by higher officials
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) 1,2,3

 

To ensure readiness for potential emergencies in a high-risk earthquake area, the following actions are crucial:

 

  1. Disaster Preparedness: Ensuring all financial and other resources are available. This involves mobilizing funds and resources for quick evacuation and emergency response.
  2. Increase Public Awareness: Conducting campaigns and using loudspeakers to inform the public about earthquake preparedness measures and safety protocols.
  3. Conduct a Simulation: Performing disaster simulations and assessing the response to identify areas for improvement and ensure the effectiveness of the emergency plan.

 

These steps are essential components of a comprehensive disaster preparedness strategy and done by someone working in a PHC situated in a high seismic zone. A medical officer is supposed to provide instructions by any communication method possible to manage through the calamity.

 

Roles and responsibilities of medical officer of PHC when posted in Seismic areas

 

  • Ensure funds and resources are available and can be mobilized at the time of disaster for quick evacuation
  • Preparedness to handle emergency
  • Disaster simulation practices and then check the response

 

Other Options:

 

While following instructions from higher officials is important during an actual disaster, it is not a proactive preparedness measure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Emergency preparedness is a programme of long-term development activities whose goals are to strengthen the overall capacity and capability of a country to manage efficiently all types of emergency. It involves the following steps:

 

  1. Disaster preparedness by making sure all financial and other resources are available
  2. Increase public awareness through campaigns and loudspeakers
  3. Conduct a simulation for the disaster and assess the response
  4. Evaluate the risk of disaster
  5. Information sessions coordination with news media
  6. Adopt standards and regulations

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the marked layer? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium and water retention

 

The image shows the adrenal gland, which is divided into the cortex and the medulla. The cortex is further subdivided into three layers: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex and is responsible for the production of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a key role in regulating sodium and water balance in the body, leading to sodium retention and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is primarily a function of the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) that promote glucose synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option C. Increased sex hormones: The zona reticularis is responsible for producing androgens, which are sex hormones. It does not contribute to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Immune cell interaction: While glucocorticoids from the zona fasciculata have some immunosuppressive effects, immune cell interaction is not a primary function of the marked layer, which is the zona glomerulosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for sodium and water retention through the secretion of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone.

choices.text: Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells)

questions.text: A child is brought to OPD with multiple skin lesions over the inner thigh and genital areas. Patient reported that it initially started as macule and later developed to become nodules. On examination, you noticed that some nodules have central umbilication. Microscopy finding is shown below. Identify the finding: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Henderson-Patterson bodies

 

Clinical history along with histological image showing intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies suggests a diagnosis of Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Molluscum contagiosum is a poxvirus infection of the skin and the mucous membranes.

 

There are four types of molluscum contagiosum viruses (MCVs), MCV-1 to -4, with MCV-1 being the most prevalent and MCV-2 being most often sexually transmitted.

 

The infections are common in young children between 2 and 12 years of age and are transmitted through direct contact or shared articles (e.g., towels).

 

Molluscum may affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk, arms, and legs. In adults, molluscum infections are typically sexually transmitted and affect the genitals, lower abdomen, buttocks, and inner thighs.

 

The average incubation period is 6 weeks.

 

Diagnosis is based on the characteristic clinical appearance of pearly, domeshaped papules with a dimpled center. The papules measure 1 to 5 mm in diameter, and their central waxy core contains cells with intracytoplasmic viral inclusions called as Molluscum bodies or Henderson Patterson bodies.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multinucleate giant cells (Tzanck cells): These are typically seen in herpesvirus infections, such as herpes simplex virus (HSV) or varicella-zoster virus (VZV) and are not related to molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option B. Donovan bodies: These are characteristic of granuloma inguinale (donovanosis), a sexually transmitted infection caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Koilocytes: These are squamous epithelial cells that have undergone specific changes due to human papillomavirus (HPV) infection. They are not seen in molluscum contagiosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henderson-Patterson bodies, which are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies, are pathognomonic for molluscum contagiosum, a poxvirus infection.

questions.text: Identify the condition in the image shown below? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cephal hematoma

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum and is typically limited by the edges of the skull bones. It does not cross suture lines because the bleeding is confined by the bone edges. This differentiates it from other types of scalp swellings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Caput succedaneum: Caput succedaneum refers to diffuse swelling of the scalp that crosses the suture lines and extends beyond the presenting part of the baby's head. It is caused by pressure from the birth canal during delivery.

 

Option C. Subgaleal hematoma: A subgaleal hematoma is a collection of blood between the scalp galea aponeurosis and the periosteum of the skull. It typically presents as a diffuse, boggy swelling that can cross suture lines and extend over large areas of the scalp.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as the image and description fit the characteristics of a cephal hematoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A cephal hematoma is a collection of blood between the skull and the periosteum, confined by the bone edges, and does not cross suture lines.

questions.text: Which of the following is autosomal dominant? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Achondroplasia

 

Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by a mutation of the fibroblast growth factor receptor-3 (FGFR-3) gene.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchene muscular dystrophy – XLR

 

Option A. Cystic fibrosis & Option C. Sickle cell anemia – Autosomal recessive

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: More common in females
Pain along V2 and V3 division of trigeminal nerve
No objective signs of sensory loss

questions.text: All are true about patients with trigeminal neuralgia except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Deep seated pain

 

Trigeminal neuralgia is characterized by sudden, severe, electric shock-like or stabbing pain that is typically superficial and localized to the face. It most often affects the V2 (maxillary) and V3 (mandibular) divisions of the trigeminal nerve. The pain associated with trigeminal neuralgia is not deep-seated but rather feels as if it is on the surface of the face, which makes option C incorrect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. More common in females: This is true. Trigeminal neuralgia is generally more common in females than in males.

 

Option B. Pain along V2 and V3 division of the trigeminal nerve: This is also true. While trigeminal neuralgia can affect any of the three branches of the trigeminal nerve, the maxillary (V2) and mandibular (V3) branches are more commonly affected than the ophthalmic (V1) branch.

 

Option D. No objective signs of sensory loss: This is correct. Trigeminal neuralgia typically does not show any objective signs of sensory loss or neurological deficit on examination, which can make diagnosis challenging.

 

Educational Objective:


Trigeminal neuralgia is marked by sharp, superficial pain that may affect the V2 and V3 divisions of the trigeminal nerve. It is important to recognize that the pain is superficial and not deep-seated. This condition more commonly affects females and presents without objective sensory loss.

 

Reference - Harrison/Trigeminal neuralgia

choices.text: D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with seizures. His past history is significant for an episode of fever with rash at 1 year of age which resolved spontaneously. What is the most helpful investigation to diagnose his condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IgG measles in CSF

 

This patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), also known as Dawson disease, which is caused by infection with the measles virus. The CSF anti-measles antibodies - IgG antibodies will be elevated and hence, it is the most helpful investigation to diagnose this condition.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B. MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis: Mesial temporal lobe sclerosis is associated with temporal lobe epilepsy, not SSPE. It involves scarring in the temporal lobe but is not typically seen in SSPE.

 

Option C. IgM measles in CSF: IgM antibodies indicate a recent infection. In SSPE, the infection occurred years earlier, so IgG antibodies, not IgM, would be elevated in the CSF.

 

Option D. D C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF: D C1Q4 antibodies are not relevant to the diagnosis of SSPE. These antibodies are associated with complement component 1q deficiency, which is linked to autoimmune conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), elevated CSF anti-measles IgG antibodies are key for diagnosis.

questions.text: Calcitonin levels are increased in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperparathyroidism

 

Calcitonin, a hormone secreted by the thyroid gland, is involved in the regulation of calcium levels in the body. In conditions where there is an increase in parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels, such as in hyperparathyroidism, there is a corresponding increase in blood calcium levels. The body responds to this hypercalcemia by increasing the secretion of calcitonin to help lower the calcium levels back to normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: While hyperthyroidism involves the thyroid gland, it does not typically result in increased calcitonin levels. Hyperthyroidism mainly increases thyroid hormones like thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3), not calcitonin.

 

Option B. Hypoparathyroidism: This condition is characterized by decreased PTH levels, leading to hypocalcemia (low calcium levels), not hypercalcemia that would stimulate calcitonin production.

 

Option D. Cushing's syndrome: Cushing's syndrome involves an excess of cortisol, a steroid hormone, and does not directly affect calcitonin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased calcitonin levels are typically seen in response to hypercalcemia, as seen in hyperparathyroidism. This is a compensatory mechanism to help maintain calcium homeostasis.

questions.text:
John is a 45-year-old male who has been experiencing a bulge in his groin area that becomes more prominent when he coughs or strains. He has been diagnosed with an inguinal hernia and is scheduled for surgery. Before the procedure, the surgeon explains the condition and its potential complications. Which of the following statements about inguinal hernias are true? (AIIMS NOV 2020)

 

  1. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by gonadal vessels
  2. Medial border of the triangle of doom is bound by Vas deferens
  3. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by rectus abdominis.
  4. Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bound by iliopsoas
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 and 3

 

Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by Vas deferens and the Medial border of myopectineal orifice is bounded by lateral border of rectus abdominis.

 

Triangle of doom boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

 

 

Myopectineal orifice of Frouchard boundaries:

 

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.
  • All groin hernia- direct inguinal, indirect inguinal and femoral occur through this orifice.

questions.text: What is the preferred diagnostic investigation for a patient presenting with this finding? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Duplex

 

  • This combines traditional ultrasound and Doppler technology to assess blood flow and the structure of blood vessels. It's the standard, first-line option for diagnosing venous insufficiency and varicose veins because it visualizes both the blood flow and the structure of the leg veins.
  • For a patient presenting with the finding shown in the image, which appears to be significant venous insufficiency or varicosities in the legs, a Duplex ultrasound is indeed the preferred diagnostic tool.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plethysmography: This test measures changes in volume within an organ or whole limb, typically used to detect abnormalities in venous filling and emptying, indicating deep vein thrombosis or chronic venous insufficiency. While useful, it doesn’t provide direct imaging of the veins.

 

Option B. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): While MRI can be used to assess veins and other vascular structures, it's generally not the first choice for examining veins in cases of suspected varicose veins due to cost and availability.

 

Option D. CT (Computed Tomography): Though CT scans provide detailed images, they are typically more useful for diagnosing issues within abdominal organs, detecting blood clots in lungs (pulmonary embolisms), or for complex vascular assessments that might require a three-dimensional view.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Duplex ultrasound is highly effective for diagnosing conditions affecting the blood vessels, like venous insufficiency, because it can directly visualize both the anatomy of the blood vessels and the movement of blood through them.

choices.text: Percentage of undernourished children under 5 years

questions.text: Which of these options is not part of the Global Hunger Index (GHI)? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Infant mortality rate

 

  • Infant mortality rate is not a component of the global hunger index (GHI).
  • The three components of the GHI are - 
    • Inadequate food supply [PNU – Undernourished Population]
    • Child mortality (under the age of 5) [U5M – Under 5 Mortality]
    • Malnutrition (wasting, stunting) [CUW – Child underweight]

 

The GHI is a tool used to measure and track hunger at global, regional, and national levels.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Global Hunger Index (GHI) does not include the infant mortality rate. It focuses on inadequate food supply, child mortality under the age of five, and child undernutrition as its key components to assess hunger and malnutrition.

questions.text: Match the following in relation to fingerprint changes: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-e, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a, 5-d

 

The changes in fingerprints can be associated with various medical conditions and external factors:

 

  1. Incomplete atrophy of ridges - E. Dermatitis:
    • Dermatitis can cause inflammation and swelling, leading to incomplete atrophy of the fingerprint ridges.
  2. Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy - C. Celiac disease:
    • Celiac disease can cause skin changes and atrophy of the fingerprint ridges, leading to the loss of pattern.
  3. Altered ridges - B. Scleroderma:
    • Scleroderma causes hardening and tightening of the skin, which can alter the fingerprint ridges.
  4. Permanent loss of fingerprints - A. Radiation:
    • Exposure to radiation can cause permanent damage to the skin, leading to the permanent loss of fingerprints.
  5. Distance between ridges is changed but pattern is retained - D. Acromegaly:
    • In acromegaly, there is an increase in the growth of bones and tissues, which can change the distance between fingerprint ridges while retaining the overall pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: 2-3 L of normal saline over 1-3 hours
Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour
Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who is known to have type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with confusion and drowsiness. Her mother says that she seems to be breathing very fast. On examination, mucous membranes are dry and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Random blood glucose is 415 mg/dL and urine ketones are 4+. What is the next best step in management? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2-3 L of Normal saline over 1-3 hours

 

IV fluids are the next best management as the patient is in shock and needs immediate correction. ABG here could show HAGMA secondary to type A lactic acidosis or ketoacidosis. Hence, ABG wouldn’t help in the diagnosis here. Shock in patient with DKA is not common and suggest an underlying sepsis as excess glucotoxicity causes shift of H2O to the intravascular compartment. IV fluid bolus is given in the emergency immediately.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin infusion at 0.1 units/kg/hour: While insulin therapy is critical in the management of DKA, it should only be started after initial fluid resuscitation has been commenced and any electrolyte imbalances, particularly potassium, have been assessed and addressed.

 

Option C. Arterial blood gas: While ABG can provide valuable information about the severity of acidosis and help guide management, it is not the immediate next step before ensuring adequate fluid resuscitation.

 

Option D. Insulin bolus of 0.1 units/kg given IV: An insulin bolus can potentially exacerbate hypokalemia in the setting of DKA. Fluid resuscitation and stabilization should precede any insulin bolus or infusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a case of DKA presenting with signs of dehydration and shock, the initial management should focus on aggressive fluid resuscitation to stabilize the patient before initiating insulin therapy. This approach not only addresses the immediate life-threatening condition but also prepares the body for further metabolic correction.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/DKA/Chapter 404

choices.text: Bone marrow aspirate
Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
Polymerase chain reaction

questions.text: A 62-year-old elderly male presented with persistent fatigue and lymph total leucocyte count of 50,000/µl. His peripheral smear was done and had the findings as shown. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

The given history of elderly male with leucocytosis and the peripheral smear showing “smudge cells” is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The diagnosis of CLL can be confirmed using flow cytometry demonstrating cells with CD5/CD23 expression.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow aspirate: While useful in some cases, it is not necessary for the initial diagnosis of CLL if flow cytometry can provide definitive results.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is useful for detecting specific genetic abnormalities but is not the first step in confirming CLL.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR can detect specific genetic mutations but is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of CLL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a suspected case of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), especially with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, flow cytometry is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis by identifying the characteristic immunophenotype of CLL cells.

questions.text:
Which among the following statements is true regarding the course of the mandibular nerve? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the temporomandibular joint.
  2. Buccal branch is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it emerges from behind the mandibular ramus.
  3. Lingual nerve is a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arcs around the submandibular duct.
  4. Ophthalmic nerve is a branch from the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, and it arises in the middle cranial fossa.
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2,3

 

Explanation:

 

Correct Statements:

 

Statement 2: True. The buccal branch, which is indeed a branch of the anterior division of the mandibular nerve, emerges from behind the mandibular ramus. This nerve primarily supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the cheek and buccal mucosa.

 

Statement 3: True. The lingual nerve, a branch from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. It famously arcs around the submandibular duct, a notable anatomical feature.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 1: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve actually arises from the posterior division of the mandibular nerve, not the anterior division, and it does indeed emerge from behind the temporomandibular joint.

 

Statement 4: Incorrect. The ophthalmic nerve is not a branch of the mandibular nerve. Instead, it is an independent division of the trigeminal nerve (V1), originating from the trigeminal ganglion located in the middle cranial fossa. It is responsible for providing sensory innervation to the forehead, scalp, and parts of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mandibular nerve's complex branching includes both sensory and motor components that are essential for facial sensation and movements. Understanding its branches, such as the buccal and lingual nerves, and their courses, is critical in dental, surgical, and diagnostic practices.

questions.text: According to antenatal care, the recommended ideal number of ANC visits should be: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 12-14

 

The recommended ideal number of antenatal care (ANC) visits is typically 12 to 14. The schedule for these visits is generally as follows:

 

  • First 7 months (up to 28 weeks): One visit per month (7 visits).
  • 8th month (29-32 weeks): Two visits in the month (2 visits).
  • 9th month (33 weeks onwards): One visit per week (4-5 visits).

 

This schedule results in a total of 13 to 14 visits during the entire pregnancy. This number ensures that both the mother and the fetus are adequately monitored throughout the pregnancy, allowing for timely identification and management of any complications.

 

Note –

 

  • Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (India): Recommends at least minimum 4 visits.
  • World Health Organization (WHO): Suggests 8 visits, referring to them as "contacts." This is to ensure a basic level of care during pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal number of antenatal care visits recommended for a normal pregnancy is 12-14 to ensure optimal monitoring and care.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presented with a noticeable swelling in his scrotum. After careful evaluation, a decision was made to perform an orchidectomy. The histopathological examination of the tissue reveals the following findings. Based on these findings which of the following diagnoses best describes the patient's condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seminoma

 

  • Morphological - well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Sheets of large, uniform, round or polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm and distinct cell borders.
  • Large central nuclei with prominent nucleoli.
  • Minimal mitotic activity and no or few infiltrating lymphocytes or Syncytiotrophoblast.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yolk-sac tumor:

  • Morphological - Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance.
  • Microscopic features include Schiller-Duval bodies (central vessel surrounded by tumor cells), which resemble a yolk sac.
  • Tumor cells have clear to eosinophilic cytoplasm with small round nuclei and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option C. Embryonal cell carcinoma:

  • Morphological - Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Composed of solid sheets or nests of primitive, undifferentiated cells.
  • Cells are variable in size and shape, with a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio and frequent mitotic figures.

 

Option D. Teratoma:

  • Morphological - Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity of tissue types.
  • Composed of multiple germ layers, including ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.
  • May contain a variety of tissues, including skin, hair, bone, cartilage, and neural tissue.
  • Immature teratomas may have undifferentiated, primitive neural or mesenchymal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Seminoma is a type of germ cell tumor characterized by large, uniform, polygonal cells with clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and prominent central nucleoli, often presenting as a well-circumscribed, gray-white, fleshy mass without hemorrhage or necrosis.

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.text: Among the following options, which statement accurately represents the relationship between prevalence of a disease and characteristics of a diagnostic test? [INICET MAY 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

 

  • The accuracy of a screening test's positive predictive value (PP) relies on the disease's prevalence.
  • PPV, which stands for positive predictive value, signifies the chance that a patient showing a positive test outcome has indeed acquired the disease.
  • In other words, it represents the probability that an individual with a positive test result genuinely possesses the disease.

 

PPV of a screening test depends on:

 

  • Sensitivity
  • Specificity
  • Prevalence of disease in the population

 

PPV of a screening test is directly proportional to the prevalence of disease in the population

 

  • PPV α Prevalence of disease
  • As the prevalence of a disease increases in a population, PPV increases for the screening test

 

Sensitivity and Specificity are independent of the prevalence the of disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive: This is misleading because in populations with a low prevalence, a positive result from even a highly sensitive test could still be a false positive due to the low likelihood of the disease.

 

Option B. Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease and Option D. Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease Sensitivity and specificity are intrinsic characteristics of a test that are determined by comparing the test results against a gold standard and are independent of disease prevalence in the population being tested. They remain constant regardless of how common or rare the disease is within that group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The positive predictive value (PPV) of a diagnostic test is significantly influenced by the prevalence of the disease within the population.
  • PPV indicates the probability that individuals who test positive actually have the disease.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought by his mother with complaints of inability to open the eyes in light and excessive watering. The clinical picture is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Congenital glaucoma

 

  • The clinical history of inability to open eyes in light (photophobia), excessive watering, and hazy cornea suggests congenital glaucoma.
  • Primary congenital glaucoma is abnormally high intraocular pressure due to a developmental anomaly of the anterior chamber angle.
  • Classification:
    1. True congenital glaucoma: IOP raised at birth.
    2. Infantile glaucoma: Disease manifests before 3 years of age.
    3. Juvenile glaucoma: IOP rises between 3-16 years of age.
  • CYP1B1 gene is implicated in the pathogenesis.
     

 

  • Other features:
    • Corneal haze due to diffuse edema from elevated IOP
    • Buphthalmos from stretching before the age of 3 years
    • Haab striae and corneal scarring can occur.

 

  • Evaluation:
    • IOP measurement
    • Corneal diameter measurement
    • Gonioscopy
    • Ophthalmoscopy

 

  • Management 
    • Surgical with goniotomy or trabeculotomy
    • If unsuccessful: trabeculectomy, tube shunt implantation, and ciliary body ablative procedures are performed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. In ophthalmia neonatorum, there will be inflammation of the conjunctiva. Clinical presentation includes conjunctival discharge, hyperaemia, chemosis, swollen eyelids, tender eyeball.

 

 

Option C. In mucopolysaccharidosis, there will be bilateral cloudy cornea.

 

 

Option D. In cataract, there will be opacification of lens presenting as whitish reflex/ leukocoria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

CAUSES OF LEUKOCORIA:

questions.text: Which of the below agents cause hypertension when consumed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cocaine

 

Cocaine is a stimulant (sympathomimetic) drug that typically leads to an increase in heart rate and blood pressure due to its effects on the cardiovascular system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Organophosphorus: Organophosphorus compounds are cholinesterase inhibitors and cause cholinergic symptoms like bradycardia, hypotension, salivation, lacrimation, urination, defecation, gastrointestinal distress, and emesis (SLUDGE syndrome). They do not cause hypertension.

 

Option B. Phosphorus: Phosphorus poisoning typically leads to gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, diarrhea), jaundice, hepatic and renal failure. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic poisoning can cause a range of symptoms including gastrointestinal distress, peripheral neuropathy, skin changes (rain drop pigmentation), Mees' lines on nails, and long-term effects like cancer. It does not cause hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine is a sympathomimetic drug and has stimulant effects on CNS and cardiovascular system as mentioned below:

 

  • Agitation and Restlessness
  • Tachycardia / Palpitations
  • Hypertension
  • Dilated Pupils
  • Profuse Sweating
  • Hyperthermia
  • Restlessness
  • Paranoia and hallucinations.
  • Serious Cardiovascular Effects: Arrhythmias, Myocardial Infarction
  • Respiratory Distress: Rapid, shallow breathing and respiratory distress.
  • Seizures, Confusion and Altered Mental Status

questions.text: Match the following named fractures with the bones involved:(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-d, 2-a, 3-b, 4-c

 

 

COMMON FRACTURE EPONYMS

 

 

1. March fracture:

  • Fatigue/stress fracture of the neck of 2nd and 3rd metatarsals.
  • More common in neck of 2nd metatarsal than 3rd metatarsal.

 

 

2. Bennett’s fracture:

  • Intra-articular fracture dislocation of base of 1st metacarpal.
  • Shaft is laterally dislocated by the unopposed pull of the abductor pollicis longus.
  • The medial projection of the thumb metacarpal base on which the volar oblique ligament attaches, remains in place.

 

 

3. Jones fracture:

  • Avulsion fracture at the base of 5th metatarsal at the metaphysio-diaphyseal junction.

 

 

4. Boxer’s fracture:

  • Fracture through the neck of 5th metacarpal.
  • More common in boxers.
